item.title: Raspberry Pi MQTT broker
item.description: In my last post I started meddling with the ESP8266 module as a low cost (and smaller) alternative to an Arduino or Raspberry Pi for creating home sensors. I was toying with the idea of sending measurements to a database using a RESTful API on the existing Postgres database I use to host measurements on Amazon Web Services. After a bit of reading, I’ve realised that there is a better solution: MQTT, a lightweight protocol designed for machine to machine (M2M) communication for sensors, and similar low powered and simple devices.

item.title: IoT with the ESP8266
item.description: I’ve been playing around with Arduinos and Raspberry Pis (mostly the latter) for a couple of years now. I’ve mostly been interested in producing Wi-Fi enables sensors that can measure things like temperature, and electricity usage throughout the home. I’m currently part way through a number of posts in which I have been analysing a year’s worth of data collected using some of these sensors, in the last post I dealt with a year’s worth of [temperature measurements]().
